caseTitle: SEMINAR ON THE TREATMENT OF OFFENDERS MODES OF ARRESTS AND T
summary: This document is a legal seminar paper by Alhaji Nuhhu Billa, a senior police officer and barrister, discussing the legal framework and practices surrounding arrests and the treatment of suspects and complainants under Ghanaian law as of 1989–1990. It outlines the definition and purpose of arrest, legal authority derived from the Criminal Procedure Code, 1960 (Act 30), and distinguishes between warrant and warrantless arrests. The paper emphasizes lawful procedures, humane treatment of suspects, rights of the accused, and the duties of police in handling complaints and detentions. It also critiques infrastructure deficiencies, such as poor police cell conditions and lack of transport, affecting effective law enforcement.
rationaleHighlights: Arrest must be justified by law and based on reasonable suspicion or commission of an offence
Suspects must be informed of the reason for arrest and treated humanely
Private persons may arrest for offences committed in their presence involving violence, theft, or fraud
All suspects are presumed innocent until proven guilty
Police must adhere to Judges' Rules and section 120(2)-(3) of NRCD 323 when taking statements
Juveniles should be released to guardians when possible
Poor infrastructure, including cells and transport, hampers effective justice delivery
confidenceNotes: The document is a legal commentary, not a judicial decision, so verdict and winning side are not applicable. Information is drawn from statutory law and police practice in Ghana circa 1989–1990. Citations are accurate and contextually relevant.
